pullRequest.body:
Adding equivalence between OnePoint K and projective line over K, as discussed at https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/.E2.9C.94.20Projective.20extended.20real.20line/near/463620378
The [first PR for this](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16152) became unable to automatically merge, so I am closing it and opening up this one.
(I do have a proof extending this to a homeomorphism for K = Real, but perhaps it is more disciplined to do the Equiv first?)

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [c7144157b0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17266/commits/c7144157b06bc9046891988d5d978f743b9b6ee5)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Compactification.OnePointEquiv`|1226|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ divOnePoint`
`+ divOnePoint'`
`+ divOnePoint_lifts`
`+ divSlope`
`+ divSlope_equiv`
`+ divSlope_inj_lifted`
`+ divSlope_injective`
`+ divSlope_inv`
`+ divSlope_surjective`
`+ slope_inv`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
I've nothing against `simp_all`, but here it seems easy to replace it with standard `simp`, so I did it.

Thanks for doing this, I'm happy this work is on its way to Mathlib ðŸŽ‰

 I'm afraid I won't have time to have a close look until the weekend. For now I just have some passing comments:

1.  The way I think about this is that if $V$ is a vector space then a choice of codimension-one affine subspace $H$ which does not contain the origin induces a bijection $â„™V \simeq H âŠ” â„™H$ (according to whether a line in $V$ meets $H$ or not). In the case that $V$ is two-dimensional, this means $H$ is one-dimensional and so $H$ is a line and $â„™H$ is a point. I can't help wondering if we might be able to simplify some of the proofs here by factoring them through this more abstract approach.
2. Notwithstanding the above, I admit it is may be worth giving special attention to situation (currently proposed) where $V$ is the plane and $H$ is the horizontal line through $(0, 1)$.
3. It looks like some of the results require `Field K` where `DivisionRing K` should work? This is not just Mathlib silliness: I think it is important that we can cover the case of the quaternionic projective line.

Anyway as I say, I'll return at the weekend and give do some proper feedback, and in the meantime, thanks again.
Thanks @ocfnash for the encouragement! I'm a bit tied up now but looking forward to thinking more about this.
Can you use a little bit less `simp_all`? `simp only` is probably enough here.
This works for any `K` with `[Zero K]  [Div K]` (not very interesting in general, but why not).
Thanks, fixed.
Can you modify the statement without using `fun`, but having variables before the `:`? Also,
Thanks, yes there was a superfluous function application which I've removed now.
Nonterminal `simp`.
Fixed.
Please try to avoid `unfold`. If you really need it, just write the corresponding `rfl` lemma (here I guess it is enough to put `divOnePoint` inside the `simp only` call).
Ah, I didn't know about putting the unfolding inside the `simp` call, thanks.
Nonterminal `simp`.
This one seems to be terminal.
Can you replace the `show` with a `rw`?
Thanks, now I've changed `m` to `m.1` in the statement of the theorem to avoid having to write `show`.
Here `a` can be implicit. Also, the name should mention something like `snd` (and if we keep this we also want the other one).
Good point, I've restructured that part of the file to make it simpler/more elegant.

This proof seems a little bit over complicated. For example
```lean
lemma not_both_zero [Zero K]
    (a : Fin 2 â†’ K) (ha : a â‰  0) (h : a 1 = 0) : a 0 â‰  0 :=
  fun H â†¦ ha <| funext fun x â†¦ by fin_cases x <;> simp [h, H]
```
works. Maybe this is even *too* golfed, but `fin_cases` is surely a good idea.
Great, I didn't know about `fin_cases` (and now I realize I could have used it many times in the past).
I think it is better to make this instance `local`.
Actually that instance is not needed so I just removed it.
We usually avoid implications in lemma statement (just write the assumption before the colon).
Thanks, fixed now.
Instead of `unfold` please write a `rfl` lemma and rewrite it.
Fixed
Same.
Fixed
Can `fin_cases` simplify the proof?
Yes! Done
Can you explicit mark this using the `TODO` keywork? In that way it is less likely we forget to remove the comment once it is done.
OK, I wrote "TODO:" there.
Can you state `h` using a `âˆ€` instead of the function? It seems more natural.
Actually it can be simply `c â€¢ b.1 = a.1`; anyway, thanks for noticing that something was off there.
This can surely go in a much more basic file (note that `Fin` is defined before mathlib, but just find a mathlbi file that works)?

Hmm... is it okay to just incorporate the proof `funext fun j => by fin_cases j <;> simp[hc,ga]` where the lemma is used, like this?
```
      have : a.1 0 â‰  0 := fun hc => .elim <|a.2 <|funext fun j => by fin_cases j <;> simp[hc,ga]
      have : b.1 0 â‰  0 := fun hc => .elim <|b.2 <|funext fun j => by fin_cases j <;> simp[hc,gb]
```

```suggestion
  funext <| fun j => by fin_cases j <;> simp [hâ‚€,hâ‚]
```

```suggestion
    Â· simp [divSlope, divOnePoint, ga, gb] at h
```

```suggestion
    Â· simp [divSlope, divOnePoint, ga, gb] at h
```

```suggestion
      Â· simp only [divSlope, divOnePoint, ite_not, Quotient.lift_mk, smul_eq_mul, ga, gb] at h
```

```suggestion
        field_simp  at h' âŠ¢
```
Oh so the âŠ¢ means "at the goal too". Didn't know about that... seems useful.

```suggestion
      Â· simp [h, ga, gb]
```

```suggestion
lemma divSlope_surjective [Field K] : Function.Surjective (@divSlope K _) :=
```
Sure

pullRequest.title: feat: Equivalence between OnePoint K and projective line over field K
